page.title: 13Colvend: Landscape
page.content: All along the coastline are steep cliffs and sandy beaches.Long ago the hidden coves and deep caves made this an ideal coastline for smugglers. Some houses in Rockcliffe are built close to the cliff and have used it to make interesting gardens. From our school,whichever way you look you will see hills and trees. The hills are grassy except for some rocks and bushes on the tops. The highest is White Hill which is 143 metres above sea level. All around are fields which change colour as the crops are grown and harvested and where cattle or sheep or horses graze peacefully. The Forestry Commission has planted fir trees above Rockcliffe and the big Dalbeattie Forest begins near White Loch,but there are still many patches of very old oak, ash and beech trees.
